newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY LEAGUE-SUPER LEAGUE AGREES TO PEACE PLAN.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY LEAGUE-SUPER LEAGUE AGREES TO PEACE PLAN.

text.p: The battle for control of rugby league in Australia moved closer to resolution on Thursday when Rupert Murdoch's rebel Super League clubs supported an Australian Rugby League (ARL) peace plan.
The 10 Super League clubs approved a proposal by the ARL, the sport's national governing body, for a unified competition in 1998, a Super League spokeswoman told Reuters.
"Our clubs were briefed on the proposal during a telephone hook-up this morning and have agreed in principle to support it," Rebecca Wilson said.
"At this stage there is nothing more we can say about it, it's now up to the ARL clubs to consider it," she said.
Both the ARL and Super League have agreed to refer the peace plan to their respective clubs after making amendments to an original ARL peace proposal at a meeting in Sydney on Wednesday.
Details about the meeting were not made public.
But Murdoch's Daily Telegraph newspaper in Sydney said on Thursday it understood the ARL had agreed to let Super League control the game's finances in return for the day-to-day running of the game.
ARL spokesman John Brady said the 12 ARL-loyal clubs would discuss the proposal later this week.
Brady told Reuters the plan did not address the emotive issue of how many clubs would be needed in a unified competition or the question of television rights.
Super League wants to establish an elite 12-team competition but the ARL wants a minimum of 16 clubs and the consensus among media commentators is that they will reach a 14-team compromise.
Murdoch launched the rebel league earlier this year primarily to provide sports programming for his local cable operation Foxtel.

He is believed to have committed about A$400 million (US$292 million) to set up and run the rebel league in Australia and the established leagues in New Zealand, Britain and France with which Super League is aligned.
The ARL is backed by Foxtel's local cable competitor Optus, which is thought to have spent about A$120 million funding the 12 ARL clubs in the main competition and the ARL itself.
